attributes.title: Meta-analysis of Commodity Prices and Conflict

q1.value: Meta-analysis of Commodity Prices and Conflict

q2.value: Graeme Blair | Darin Christensen | Aaron Rudkin

q5.value: We thank Maryam Aljafen, Macartan Humphreys, Michael Ross, Valerie Wirtschafter, and the UCLA Improving Designs in the Social Sciences workshop for helpful comments.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Political scientists and economists have assembled a body of research assessing the causal relationship between commodity prices and conflict (Dube and Vargas 2013; Bazzi and Blattman 2014; Christensen 2018). Results have been mixed. On the one hand Bazzi and Blattman (2014) state definitively “Price shocks have no effect on new conflict, even large shocks in high-risk nations.” Yet, Dube and Vargas (2013), to take a prominent example, find that conflict increases in Colombia’s oil-producing municipalities as the international price for oil goes up. These findings could be due to theoretical choices about what types of conflicts or commodities to study, or design decisions about what cases to sample or the most credible empirical strategy. Both the outpouring of recent research and its conflicting findings motivate this meta-analysis. We believe there is now a critical mass of studies that address the question, how do commodity price changes affect civil conflict? Moreover, these studies share a concern with causal identification and employ methods that exploit exogenous, inter-temporal variation in food, fuel, or mineral prices. Despite these commonalities, these studies also differ in ways that might explain their divergent findings. We seek to define the theoretically relevant dimensions and specify when and how we’ll test for heterogeneity across studies.

q18.value: Meta-analysis of single- and multi-country studies.

registration_responses.q1: Meta-analysis of Commodity Prices and Conflict
registration_responses.q2: Graeme Blair | Darin Christensen | Aaron Rudkin
registration_responses.q5: We thank Maryam Aljafen, Macartan Humphreys, Michael Ross, Valerie Wirtschafter, and the UCLA Improving Designs in the Social Sciences workshop for helpful comments.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

Results have been mixed. On the one hand Bazzi and Blattman (2014) state definitively “Price shocks have no effect on new conflict, even large shocks in high-risk nations.” Yet, Dube and Vargas (2013), to take a prominent example, find that conflict increases in Colombia’s oil-producing municipalities as the international price for oil goes up. These findings could be due to theoretical choices about what types of conflicts or commodities to study, or design decisions about what cases to sample or the most credible empirical strategy. Both the outpouring of recent research and its conflicting findings motivate this meta-analysis. We believe there is now a critical mass of studies that address the question, how do commodity price changes affect civil conflict? Moreover, these studies share a concern with causal identification and employ methods that exploit exogenous, inter-temporal variation in food, fuel, or mineral prices. Despite these commonalities, these studies also differ in ways that might explain their divergent findings. We seek to define the theoretically relevant dimensions and specify when and how we’ll test for heterogeneity across studies.
registration_responses.q18: Meta-analysis of single- and multi-country studies.

attributes.title: How Voters Evaluate Allegations of Sexual Misconduct Against Politicians

q1.value: How Voters Evaluate Allegations of Sexual Misconduct Against Politicians

q2.value: John McAndrews | Roosmarijn De Geus | Peter Loewen

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The aim of this project is to investigate how voters evaluate allegations of sexual misconduct against politicians and to assess how voters' partisanship and gender identity shape such judgments.

q16.value: We evaluate the effect of sexual misconduct allegations on the likelihood of voting for the politician, as well as on how voters describe the politician. In addition, we evaluate the effect of various features of the allegations (including the type of misconduct, number of women making allegations, and the status of the investigation into the allegations) on voters' judgments about the politician and on their beliefs about the allegations. Lastly, we evaluate how these effects depend on voters' partisanship and gender identity. A complete set of hypotheses is provided in the attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: We will test our hypotheses using two conjoint experiments. We will estimate treatment effects, average marginal component effects, and conditional component effects using OLS. Complete details on the estimation strategy are provided in the attached pre-analysis plan. The complete survey instrument is also attached.

attributes.title: Who Can Best Dispel WhatsApp Rumors? Experimental Evidence from India

q1.value: Who Can Best Dispel WhatsApp Rumors? Experimental Evidence from India

q2.value: Simon Chauchard | D.J. Flynn | Sumitra Badrinathan

q5.value: Thanks to Ipsa Arora, Ritubhan Gautam, and Hanmant Wanole for research assistance. Funding is from Facebook. The thors thank Alex Leavitt and Devra Moelher at Facebook, as well as participants of the Facebook Integrity Research Workshop (June 2019).

q8.value: Registration after researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Misinformation is a growing concern across the world and particularly in developing countries such as India, where false or unsupported claims can distort public opinion, undermine faith in democratic institutions, and endanger public health. In recent years, messages containing misinformation about electoral security, terrorism, HIV/AIDS, and vaccine safety have circulated widely in the country, arguably leading to a slay of problematic behaviors offline (murders, riots, and other harmful behaviors), and possibly affecting the outcome of elections (Sinha et al 2019). Following a trend started in the United States in the mid 2010s, a host of organizations and institutions have over the past two years launched initiatives to correct online misinformation. Actors connected to the state (officials, policemen, teachers), domain experts, journalists, fact-checking organizations and social media platforms themselves have joined in on this effort. Yet we so far lack evidence as to the relative efficiency of these multiple types of corrections. How do the sources of misinformation and the sources of corrections affect people’s belief in various claims? Whose corrections, if any at all, can best dispel online rumors? As we investigate this question, we more generally provide evidence about the effectiveness of corrective messages in India. We also investigate the potential interaction of correction with partisanship; while studies set in the American contest have repeatedly shown the influence of motivated reasoning on information processing (Taber and Lodge 2006; Nyhan and Reifler 2012), no such evidence exists in contexts such as India in which partisan affiliations may be less strong or stable in the first place. We investigate these questions with a survey experiment conducted on a sample of Hindi-speaking Facebook users. Our experiment examines the effectiveness of corrective messages included on a WhatsApp thread. We show respondents screenshots of a fictitious but credible WhatsApp thread (a thread they are themselves not part of) featuring a controversial claim. Our experiment then examines the effect of including various types of corrective messages on the belief in the claim discussed earlier in the thread. As such, this is the first study on misinformation and correction to engage with the discursive format of the dominant social media in the Indian context, and in much of the developing world, the Facebook-owned WhatsApp messaging app.

q16.value: H1: Exposure to corrective information on WhatsApp will reduce the perceived accuracy of the targeted claim relative to a pure control condition. H2a: WhatsApp corrections will be more effective when the targeted claim is attributed to a dissonant politician (compared to when it is unattributed). H2b: WhatsApp corrections will be less effective when the targeted claim is attributed to a congenial politician (compared to when it is unattributed). H3a: WhatsApp corrections will be more effective when the targeted claim originates from a dissonant media outlet (compared to an unattributed or neutral outlet). H3b: WhatsApp corrections will be less effective when the targeted claim originates from a congenial media outlet (compared to an unattributed or neutral outlet). H4a: WhatsApp corrections will be less effective when the targeted claim is ideologically congenial to respondents (compared to non-ideological claims). H4b: WhatsApp corrections will be more effective when the targeted claim is ideologically dissonant to respondents (compared to non-ideological claims). Besides, in line with the aforementioned main objective of our study, we also investigate the following research question on which we have weaker theoretical priors: RQ1: Which types of corrections are most efficient at reducing misinformation? Are professional fact checking outlets more effective at combating misinformation than domain experts and/or platforms (i.e., WhatsApp)?

registration_responses.q1: Who Can Best Dispel WhatsApp Rumors? Experimental Evidence from India
registration_responses.q2: Simon Chauchard | D.J. Flynn | Sumitra Badrinathan
registration_responses.q5: Thanks to Ipsa Arora, Ritubhan Gautam, and Hanmant Wanole for research assistance. Funding is from Facebook. The thors thank Alex Leavitt and Devra Moelher at Facebook, as well as participants of the Facebook Integrity Research Workshop (June 2019).

attributes.title: Testing the “Howard Hypothesis”: Do changes in the perception of border security affect support for immigration?

q1.value: Testing the “Howard Hypothesis”: Do changes in the perception of border security affect support for immigration?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The goal of the article is to test the idea that support for immigration is conditioned by perceptions of border security. I call this the “Howard Hypothesis,” as former Australian PM John Howard has referenced this idea in numerous public statements. The question of the link between border security and attitudes towards immigration has practical value for understanding the stakes in fights over border allocations, and it also may show an additional way that people make sociotropic judgements around immigration.

q16.value: I will test how preferences over levels of immigration vary in response to changes in spending on border security.

q17.value: I run two distinct experiments on a sample of 1000 Americans. In brief: the first asks for the respondent’s ideal level of immigration and then provides randomly assignments treatments describing changes in spending on border security and again asks the respondent for their ideal level of immigration. The second experiment is a conjoint experiment with a small treatment space. I have two IVs, change in spending on border security and change in immigration level, each with 9 levels of change (-20%, -15% -10, -5%, no change, +5%, +10%, +15%, +20%). This leaves 81 unique profiles. Each respondent picks between 7 pairs of profiles, so I should fully saturate the space. I will be testing if respondents are more likely to choose profiles with higher immigration rates if they are accompanied by higher spending on border security. For more information, see the pre-registration plan and/or the accompanying complete pipeline of data cleaning and analysis code.

q19.value: 1000 respondents will take the survey, but the survey will lead to n≈1,950 for the first experiment (I am dropping outliers and I can’t predict exactly how many will drop, but it should be between 40 and 80) and n=14,000 for the second experiment.

registration_responses.q1: Testing the “Howard Hypothesis”: Do changes in the perception of border security affect support for immigration?
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

The question of the link between border security and attitudes towards immigration has practical value for understanding the stakes in fights over border allocations, and it also may show an additional way that people make sociotropic judgements around immigration.

For more information, see the pre-registration plan and/or the accompanying complete pipeline of data cleaning and analysis code.

attributes.title: Does veneering technique affect the bond strength of bilayer Y-TZP? A systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: This systematic review is in accordance to the PRISMA statement. The “PICOs” for this systematic review is defined as follows:  Population: specimens with any geometry comprising Y-TZP framework; Intervention: veneering technique based on Cad-on or overpressing procedures; Comparison: manual layering veneering method; Outcomes: Shear, microtensile and retentive bond strengths; Study design: in vitro studies.

q1.value: Does veneering technique affect the bond strength of bilayer Y-TZP? A systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Iana Lamadrid Aurélio, Ana Maria Marchionatti

q3.value: Reasons for failures of bilayer yttria-stabilized tetragonal zirconia polycrystal (Y-TZP) restorations include the core/veneer interface bond strength. The influence of the veneering method on the bond strength of veneered Y-TZP is currently unclear.  So, the purpose of this systematic review was to evaluate the effect of the veneering method on the bond strength of bilayer Y-TZP.

q4.value: The null hypothesis tested was that no difference would be found in the bond strength regardless of the veneering process.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: The titles and abstracts were independently reviewed by 2 authors (A.M.E.M and I.L.A.). Studies were selected for complete reading if the titles and abstracts met the inclusion criteria with the consensus of both authors. The calculated interexaminer Kappa was 0.91. The full-text articles were reviewed, and those that did not meet any exclusion criteria were included (Kappa = 0.92). The references of the selected papers were manually reviewed, and the full-texts of the studies that could potentially fulfill the inclusion criteria were examined. Data were independently extracted by the same two reviewers (A.M.E.M and I.L.A.).

question.value: The PICOs strategy was defined as follows: Population: specimens with any geometry comprising Y-TZP framework; Intervention: pressed, cemented, or fused veneer on Y-TZP framework; Comparison: hand-layered veneer on Y-TZP; Outcome: bond strength; Study design: in vitro studies.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: The inclusion criteria for study selection were: in vitro studies; using specimens with Y-TZP framework covered by a ceramic veneer; and evaluating bond strength, regardless of the mechanical testing configuration adopted, either immediately or after aging. The final decision on the inclusion was based on the full-text analysis of the potentially relevant studies. Studies that did not have the following items were excluded: at least 1 group with the hand-layered technique; at least 1 group with pressed, fused or cemented veneering technique; and bond strength quantitative means, standard-deviations, and sample sizes of the groups. If means, standard-deviations or sample size results were missing or described in graphs or figures, the authors were contacted via e-mail for information requirement.

q13.value: From 619 identified studies, 499 remained after duplicates removal. From this, 359 studies were excluded because they did not meet the inclusion criteria. From the 140 remaining studies selected for full-text analysis, 124 were excluded. A total of 16 articles were included in the systematic review, of which 15 were included in the meta-analyses and 1 was used only in the descriptive analysis. Manual searching yielded no additional studies.

question.value: Outcome measure: bond strength values (in MPa)

Meta-analyses compared the bond strength (in MPa) of hand-layered (control) to pressed, cemented, and fused veneering techniques. Data from cemented and fused methods were analyzed by subgroups divided by the type of veneering ceramic – predominantly glass-ceramics and particle-filled glass-ceramics (lithium disilicate and leucite-reinforced ceramics) –in comparison with the hand-layered veneering method. When applicable, specific formulas were used to combine data from multiple groups of the same study into single sample sizes, means, and standard-deviations ( Higgins J, Green S (editors). Cochrane handbook for systematic reviews of interventions version 5.1.0 [updated March 2011]. The Cochrane Collaboration, 2011. Available at: http://handbook.cochrane.org. Accessed August 10, 2017). The pooled effect estimates were obtained by comparing the means of each of the bond strength values, and these estimates were expressed as the raw mean difference among the groups. A P value ≤.05 was considered as statistically significant (Z test). The statistical heterogeneity among the studies was assessed using both the Cochran Q test, in which a P value <.1 was considered statistically significant, and the inconsistency I2 test, in which values higher than 50% indicated substantial heterogeneity (Higgins). Analyses were performed with Review Manager Software 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration).

registration_responses.q1: Does veneering technique affect the bond strength of bilayer Y-TZP? A systematic review and meta-analysis
registration_responses.q2: Iana Lamadrid Aurélio, Ana Maria Marchionatti

So, the purpose of this systematic review was to evaluate the effect of the veneering method on the bond strength of bilayer Y-TZP.

q2.value: Dustin Calvillo, Abraham M. Rutchick, Thomas Smelter

q3.value: In previous studies, we found that Republicans and Democrats differ in their ability to discern true from fake news about COVID-19, and in their knowledge about the virus, and its perceived threat. The purpose of this study is to further examine differences in news discernment, and to collect another time point that examined differences in threat perception.

q4.value:
As in Study 1, we predict that H1) participants will rate true headlines as more accurate than false headlines He also predict that Republicans (compared to Democrats) will H2a) perform worse on news discernment, H3a) rate their vulnerability as lower, H4a) rate the severity as lower, H5a) agree more with a conspiracy statement, and H6a) agree more with a media exaggeration statement. We will also compute correlational analyses and predict that H2b) will be negatively correlated with news discernment, H3b) will be negatively correlated with vulnerability ratings, H4b) will be negatively correlated with severity ratings, H5b) will be positively correlated with conspiracy ratings, and H6b) will be positively correlated with media exaggeration ratings. 
We also predict that Democrats will score higher in knowledge about COVID19 (H7a), and conservatism will be negatively correlated with COVID19 knowledge (H7b). 
Finally, we predict that Democrats will score higher on the CRT (H8a), and conservatism will be negatively correlated with CRT performance (H8b).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a correlational design. For some analyses, there is one quasi-independent variable (political party: Republican, Democrat).

q9.value: The order of the headlines will be randomized for each participant. The order of the news sources will also be randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data on Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Participants will be paid for completing the study.

q13.value: We will collect data until we have at least 462 participants who pass both honesty check questions.

q14.value: In Study 1 and 2, the smallest correlation between conservatism and an outcome was r = .13. Based on this effect size, we will need 462 participants to have a power of .80 (with two-tailed alpha = .05).

q15.value: We will collect data from 500 participants and determine if 462 of them passed both honesty checks. Based on that result, we will run additional batches of participants until we have at least 462.

question.value: We will measure: ratings to true and false coronavirus news headlines, perceived vulnerability to the coronavirus, perceived severity of the virus, conspiracist beliefs about the coronavirus, perception of media exaggeration of the risks of the coronavirus, knowledge about COVID19, and cognitive reflection. We will also measure political ideology (party, liberal-conservatism scale, and support for Trump).
News discernment will be calculated by subtracting mean ratings of fake headlines from mean ratings of true headlines.
We will test hypothesis 1 with a paired-samples t-test, hypotheses 2a-8a with independent samples t-tests, and hypotheses 2b-8b with Pearson correlations.

q21.value: We will set alpha = .05 and reject null hypotheses in cases in which the p-value is less than alpha.

q22.value: We will exclude data from participants who respond "yes" to either of the two honesty check questions (did they respond randomly to any items; did they look up any headlines/questions).

q23.value: Participants who do not rate more than one headline will be excluded. Participants who do not provide political party ratings or any of the coronavirus (threat, vulnerability, etc) ratings will also be excluded. Participants who do not identify as Republican or Democrat will be excluded from the between-group analyses, but they will be included in the correlational analyses.

q24.value: We will also explore how the level of support for Trump relate to responses on all tasks, including potential moderation of correlations. We will also examine mediation of the relationships between conservatism and ratings of vulnerability and severity with knowledge and news discernment. Finally, we will explore how media diet affects news discernment, COVID19 knowledge, ratings of vulnerability, severity, media exaggeration, and conspiracy belief.

registration_responses.q2: Dustin Calvillo, Abraham M. Rutchick, Thomas Smelter
registration_responses.q3: In previous studies, we found that Republicans and Democrats differ in their ability to discern true from fake news about COVID-19, and in their knowledge about the virus, and its perceived threat. The purpose of this study is to further examine differences in news discernment, and to collect another time point that examined differences in threat perception.
registration_responses.q4:
As in Study 1, we predict that H1) participants will rate true headlines as more accurate than false headlines He also predict that Republicans (compared to Democrats) will H2a) perform worse on news discernment, H3a) rate their vulnerability as lower, H4a) rate the severity as lower, H5a) agree more with a conspiracy statement, and H6a) agree more with a media exaggeration statement. We will also compute correlational analyses and predict that H2b) will be negatively correlated with news discernment, H3b) will be negatively correlated with vulnerability ratings, H4b) will be negatively correlated with severity ratings, H5b) will be positively correlated with conspiracy ratings, and H6b) will be positively correlated with media exaggeration ratings. 
We also predict that Democrats will score higher in knowledge about COVID19 (H7a), and conservatism will be negatively correlated with COVID19 knowledge (H7b). 
Finally, we predict that Democrats will score higher on the CRT (H8a), and conservatism will be negatively correlated with CRT performance (H8b).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: The order of the headlines will be randomized for each participant. The order of the news sources will also be randomized for each participant.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will collect data until we have at least 462 participants who pass both honesty check questions.
registration_responses.q14: In Study 1 and 2, the smallest correlation between conservatism and an outcome was r = .13. Based on this effect size, we will need 462 participants to have a power of .80 (with two-tailed alpha = .05).
registration_responses.q15: We will collect data from 500 participants and determine if 462 of them passed both honesty checks. Based on that result, we will run additional batches of participants until we have at least 462.
registration_responses.q21: We will set alpha = .05 and reject null hypotheses in cases in which the p-value is less than alpha.
registration_responses.q22: We will exclude data from participants who respond "yes" to either of the two honesty check questions (did they respond randomly to any items; did they look up any headlines/questions).
registration_responses.q23: Participants who do not rate more than one headline will be excluded. Participants who do not provide political party ratings or any of the coronavirus (threat, vulnerability, etc) ratings will also be excluded. Participants who do not identify as Republican or Democrat will be excluded from the between-group analyses, but they will be included in the correlational analyses.
registration_responses.q24: We will also explore how the level of support for Trump relate to responses on all tasks, including potential moderation of correlations. We will also examine mediation of the relationships between conservatism and ratings of vulnerability and severity with knowledge and news discernment. Finally, we will explore how media diet affects news discernment, COVID19 knowledge, ratings of vulnerability, severity, media exaggeration, and conspiracy belief.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a correlational design. For some analyses, there is one quasi-independent variable (political party: Republican, Democrat).
registration_responses.q12.question: We will collect data on Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Participants will be paid for completing the study.
registration_responses.q16.question: None
registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure: ratings to true and false coronavirus news headlines, perceived vulnerability to the coronavirus, perceived severity of the virus, conspiracist beliefs about the coronavirus, perception of media exaggeration of the risks of the coronavirus, knowledge about COVID19, and cognitive reflection. We will also measure political ideology (party, liberal-conservatism scale, and support for Trump).
registration_responses.q18.question: News discernment will be calculated by subtracting mean ratings of fake headlines from mean ratings of true headlines.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will test hypothesis 1 with a paired-samples t-test, hypotheses 2a-8a with independent samples t-tests, and hypotheses 2b-8b with Pearson correlations.
